replacement.value: This template demonstrates the "{\b Levenshtein Distance}" of two given texts.\line\line The Levenshtein Distance was considered by Vladimir Levenshtein in 1965. It is also called the "edit distance". It is defined by the minimum amount of edits (insert, remove, replace) of single characters to change one text into the other.\line\line In this template the text "This is a test of the Levenshtein Distance" is compared to "This is a Xtest of the LevenshteinXXX DistaXce". The "Expected Text" could be the expected text in a data transmission. The "Text with Errors" could be a received text with errors. The Levenshtein Distance between these two texts is 5. To generate the one text out of the other, the first "X" (first error) has to be changed to "t". Then, three errors ("XXX") have to be removed. Finally, "DistaXce" has to be changed to "Distance". In sum, we have 1 replace, 3 removals, and 1 replace, which is added to a total Levenshtein Distance of 5.\line\line For more information have a look at: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenshtein_distance
